he 's a rose-breasted cockatoo .they 're native to australia , and floyd is approximately six years old .he can be quite a talker .many birds talk .some do n't .for those of us who love them , it matters not whether they do , or they do n't .it does n't change the amount we love them .however , floyd says a number of things , and. [CLS] [SEP]i 'm hoping he 'll say them today , and i 'm going to test that theory right now .give me a kiss .give me a kiss .many people are curious as to why birds talk , or how they talk .they actually do n't have a voice box as we do .they have air sacs , and they 're able to talk by manipulating air , over and through those air sacs .why do they talk ?they talk for a couple of reasons .generally , they talk because they 've heard something that they like , and they enjoy replicating sounds .floyd says , as i said , a number of things , and he also says what a cute bird , what a cute floyder .i do n't know that he 'll go through that whole repertoire today , and i would tend to doubt it , because the other thing is , that birds do n't always do what you want them to do .they seem to exercise a fair amount of free will , so if you ever see someone performing with a bird , and the bird is talking quite a bit , that means probably that the bird is happy , and that the bird is very well focused .it 's very difficult to get a bird to perform in front of an audience , that they 're not familiar with .in fact , often , it 's difficult to get them to perform in front of an audience at all , so appreciate those people who train them , so that they can do that .floyd , and a lot of other birds , will also talk a lot when i 'm not paying much attention to them .i have , and some of the best talkers , are this little guy , again a rose-breasted cockatoo .also , a number of the amazons , and i have a couple of amazons , who will say hello , and say it louder and louder , until i acknowledge them .birds have learned that we pay attention , i guess , when they talk , and they do it for that reason , so let 's see if floyd is going to talk again .what a cute bird .oh , he liked that .you going to give me a kiss ?give me a kiss .give me a kiss .give me a kiss .he also makes the kissing noise , which is kind of cute , but he does have a repertoire .i think he 's going to limit it today , because he 's trying to play hard to get .if you 're trying to teach a bird to talk , just remember they 're a lot like children .if you want them to talk , you need to talk to them .a lot of people say to me , my bird does n't talk , and they sound disappointed in that .just speak to your bird , and you 'll find that like a child , many of them will respond .

hi , i 'm travis corpening , and i 'm about to teach you , just how to do a reverse layup .here we are at carolina beach recreation center , and the first thing you want to do , when you 're trying to do a reverse layup , is you want to be able to jump from one side of the goal , at least to the other side of the rim , so once you take off , you want to position yourself to where , when you 're taking off , you 're already prepared , before you even jump .you 're all ready prepared , to make it , on the other side of the rim .now , by preparing yourself before you get to the other side of the rim , what you do is , you allow yourself more time to adjust to the defense , to have your mind and body adjust to the defense , for whatever may happen , while you 're in the air , so that you can complete the shot , so what you do , is you take off , reach with your opposite hand .if you 're coming from the left side of the basket , you want to complete it with your right hand .if you 're coming from the right side of the basket , you want to complete it with your left hand , but you can interchange , if you 're skilled enough .after you come from the other side of the basket , you want to reach around , and you either want to spin it , or you want to tap it , right in the middle of the box , over the top of the rim .once you do this , practice it a few times , and it 's a really effective shot , during the game , when you 're in a tight squeeze , and the defense is really playing you down low .there you have it , the reverse layup .
because this is one thing that you can not fake at all .sincerity is one thing that you have to have it. [CLS] [SEP]or you do n't .you can smile ; you can do these little things that really enhance how you 're going to sound .especially to the listeners .it 's one thing , when we 're sharing a medium like television right now , but when you 're communicating with someone on the radio , they 're listening to you .you may be talking to a whole lot of people , but it 's one at a time .and you 've got to have that sincerity .the way that you address the client , you 've got to know your audience .and with mic technique as well .we all want to have that big , bassy voice , but you 're stuck with what you 're blessed with .you can use different mics that may enhance and try to add a bit more bass to your voice .but once again , listeners do n't really care too much about that .they want to hear someone that they feel comfortable listening to .someone that has that sincerity , that friendly voice , someone that they can listen to .because they have that friendship , they have that bond with you .they 're going to listen to you for a long time .you 've got to have that sincerity .sincerity works , and that 'll keep you going for years to come .

[CLS] [SEP]so you do n't get confused , ok.my left leg is take off .my left leg and my feet are pushing in to board to get power , to make the board bend .my right leg is going to come up , still a 90 degree angle .it 's going to look like an l , ok.remember , you 're right foot now is tucked in to your left knee .that 's what happens on your legs in the hurdle part of diving .

auto play mode is a mode for playback of images that will automatically play all of the images , in sequence , that you 've taken and shot , on your memory card .it 's useful for , it 's kind of like a slide show .it 's useful for displaying your work , without actually having to pull it off of your camera .what you can do , also , is hook up your camera to a larger screen for viewing .but in our case , we 're just going to play back the images automatically on our 40d .to get to this option , you need to press the menu button , which is in the top left corner of your camera .go ahead and press `` menu '' .and , i 'm going to scroll over here to the second playback menu .it 's a blue , it 's got a blue icon up here at the top of the triangle pointing to your right , and there will be two dots in the upper right hand corner .once i 'm on that menu , i can scroll down with my quick control dial to auto play .auto play is highlighted with a blue rectangle , and i 'm just going to press `` set '' .now auto play is loading .it should begin playing my images for a couple of seconds at a time , and then switching to the next image in that sequence .and you can see that it 's actually rotating through the images sequentially .i 've got 26 images , and i 'm playing number 14 , now number 15 , and number 16.and , to pause this , i 'm going to press `` set '' .the playback mode will just be paused .that image will continue to be displayed .but , if i want to exit from the auto play mode , image mode , i just need to press `` menu '' again up here on the top left of your body .go ahead and press `` menu '' , and that takes you all the way back to the menu .and you can navigate to a different option in your menu or exit completely .

illegal or prescription drugs and try to swap it in , for their own .what this temperature strip will tell you is , whether or not the urine has come fresh from the body or is cold , due to the fact alright let 's talk to f major scale .you 're going to be up in the side keys , high , real heavy again just like the last time .starting on f we will just go through the fingerings .it starts off with the low f , g , a , b flat , c , d , e , f , your middle f , f , g , a , b flat , c. [CLS] [SEP]moving up after that d with your side key. [CLS] [SEP]so you have got all three side keys with the insides of your fingers just like that , the octave key and this side key. [CLS] [SEP]and that is your high f.it is actually kind of difficult to play as a beginner .i think i struggled with the high register of the horn a lot .so it is something that you need to practice , do n't get frustrated. [CLS] [SEP]just work it out and. [CLS] [SEP]like we said before you can always start up high just to get yourself up there .so you are really going to need to work the upper register out .we went over the f major scale , let 's play it , here we go two octaves , f major .pretty simple , work that out nice and slow .you can go up in speed nice and slowly but remember to work out that upper register you can use a few keys up top to keep practicing that .there is no need to go up and down on the scale but use your metronome and get it right , okay .
okay , our last cue ball action that we can use in conjunction with the tangent line is backspin .backspin is nothing more than the same spin that we put on the cue ball when we were using a draw shot .but , now on our draw shot , that was when the two balls were lined up straight for a straight in shot , we could get the cue ball to come straight back to us .but what happens when we 're at an angle like this ?we already know that we ca n't get the cue ball to come straight back because of the angle .so , what 's going to happen here. [CLS] [SEP]is we have to look at our tangent line again. [CLS] [SEP], we 're going to identify it as running , pretty much , that direction right there .now , if we have a backspin on the cue ball , what 's going to happen here is , it 's spinning backwards , comes over , hits that contact point , starts out on the tangent line but only follows it for a very short distance , once again .that distance is only about an inch .maybe a little more , maybe a little less , that 's depending on the speed that you hit it with .but , it 'll start out on that. [CLS] [SEP]and it 'll go that direction for a very short distance. [CLS] [SEP], then the backspin will take over , and it will arc back this direction , to the right in this case because our cut shot is to the left .so , a draw shot using backspin would look like this .comes over that way .
i would like to show you a couple of examples real quick of a good corner and a bad corner .a good corner would be when the two edges meet and they line up. [CLS] [SEP]and they are nice and straight and flush .this right here would be an example of a good corner .now i 'm going to demonstrate to you what a bad corner would look like .this right here would be a bad corner and the reason it would be a bad corner. [CLS] [SEP]is because both drywalls from both sides of here do not meet up straight inside here and since it did that there is no meat for this to grab on to right here. [CLS] [SEP]and it just makes it harder for it to set in place .now as long as it is straight which is it , when we installed it we made sure that the corner bead did go on straight .it is still alright .although it would be better if the drywall ran underneath this .now the reason this happened is probably a sheet was cut and put into place and it was just accidentally cut wrong which happens .so we try to avoid that .it is kind of like screwing your screw in too far .we really try to avoid that. [CLS] [SEP]and we try and get all our corners perfect but once in a while when one does happen , if we can still make it look perfect and it will work out then sometimes we just go ahead with it .

and what we are going to demonstrate and talk about is how to clear the obstructed airway .the obstructed airway can be cleared by using the finger sweep technique .before we attempt any type of finger sweep technique we have to determine if the airway is actually obstructed .the first thing we would do is tilt the head using the chin lift technique and try to deliver rescue breathes after we look , listen and feel to determine if the victim is exchanging air .if they are not exchanging air because of an airway obstruction , we would deliver two rescue breaths like forcefully , pinching off the nose and covering the patient 's mouth and blowing air down through the airway .if air will not go through we would reposition the head unless we suspect a spinal cord injury .if there is a spinal cord injury we would leave the head in the position found and use the jaw thrust technique of reaching into the mouth , grabbing under the chin , grabbing the tongue and pulling the jaw and the tongue forward , towards the feet .we would then look inside the airway to see if we see the obstruction and if we see the obstruction , take a finger and do a blind finger sweep through the mouth and the airway to try and eliminate the obstruction .then try and deliver rescue breaths once again .activate the emergency response system and wait for arrival of responding emt 's and paramedics .i 'm captain joe bruni , stay safe and we will see you next time .

what do you need to play baseball ?well , let 's look inside the bat bag and find out .bat bag is the number one thing you 'll find every serious baseball player has .it 's an easy way to get your equipment to and from the game .first thing you need , obviously a baseball .this is a standard baseball .they 're all pretty much the same .you 'll need a glove .gloves come in various sizes .we 'll talk about that a little bit later .this is just a standard outfielder 's glove here .you 'll need some cleats .these will help you to navigate the field of play , help you dig in on the dirt a little bit better so you wo n't slip and slide .these are an optional piece of equipment for your batting gloves .these help you get a better grip on the bat .some people wear them under their fielding glove to add a little bit more padding .they 've got a nice , sticky surface here. [CLS] [SEP]that gives you get a good grip on the bat , helps you swing and control what you 're doing .and then , probably the most important thing , especially for those of us who like the offense of the game of baseball is your bat .this is just a standard aluminum bat .you 'll find this all over the country and various forms of the game .in the major league game , they play with a wooden bat .but this , you 'll find on most other level .and that 's pretty much all you need to play the game baseball .

and this is actually a white building .now , how did we create this pink glow ?somebody said to me when the exhibition opened , that i must of used a pink filter .no .this was shot in the middle of the summer , during a thunderstorm .and the thunderstorm had just cleared over the building , and most of the sky was pretty dark .but just as the sun was going below the horizon , it just popped out , hit the underside of cumolonimbus clouds , and reflected onto the building , creating this amazing pink glow .so do n't be scared when the weather is bad to go out and shoot , you might get some amazing results .this photograph was taken with the telephoto lens , actually this lens here , a 100 to 400 cannon image stabilize lens .the essence of this , is that you need to go out during inclement weather conditions to create unusual photographs .do n't be scared to go out when the sun is not out .

in this segment i 'm going to talk about controlling a swing .to swing only as big as you can control .for example , if you were trying to hit a nail into a wall and with a swing or a hit this big , you bent the nail , bent the nail , bent the nail. [CLS] [SEP], what are the chances that you could hit that nail straight in with this swing ?slim to none .you 'd have to be very lucky .and that is the point with the hammer swing .and something that helps tremendously , and that is to swing only as big as you can control .for example , if you could control a swing this big and hit it straight in , and you practice it , then you could get a little bigger and practice it and a little bigger and practice it .but , when you get on the first tee , if you have trouble hitting a nail in at that speed and that length , what are your chances of hitting that nail straight in at this speed and this length ?you have to be lucky .and that 's why you have to be realistic with the hammer swing .so , when you hit and you practice , practice small and hit that nail straight in .practice a little bigger , hit it straight in .but , as soon as you start hitting it crooked and bending that nail , take it down a notch .swing only as big and as hard as you can control .and that 's what 's so great about the hammer swing .it gets you realistic .hit it in little .hit it in a little bigger .hit it in a little bigger .hit it in big , oh , you ca n't hit it straight like that ?take it down a notch .hit the ball straighter .swing within yourself with the hammer swing .

[CLS] [SEP]group juggle is you 're going to get everyone in the room in a circle .go over names. [CLS] [SEP]so you make sure everybody knows each other 's names .then one person is going to start .if i was starting , i 'm going to make eye contact with someone else in the circle .see over there ?i 'm going to make eye contact with david .i 'm going to say his name , david .and then i 'm going to gently underhandedly toss him the caterpillar or the ball .once he 's caught it , i 'm going to cross myself off and make a little x in front of myself , because i only want to toss the ball once .and this is going to let people know not to throw it to me again .so once david has it , he 's going to throw it to angela , angela 's going to throw it to steve and so on and. [CLS] [SEP]so forth until everybody 's received the ball once and everybody has crossed out .the very last person , they 're going to throw it back to me , shana , and. [CLS] [SEP]i 'm going to catch it .so that will be our pattern .i 'll remind everybody to remember the person you threw it to because you 're going to continue to throw it to that person .so then what we do is we repeat the pattern , just to make sure we 've got it .i throw it to david , to angela and so on .then what i do is i say , we 're going to try this with more .so we 're going to have four going instead of one , on that same pattern .so we 've got these balls tossing in the air. [CLS] [SEP]and they 're going to sometimes collide with each other , people are going to get stressed out because more is coming down the line .and suddenly things are getting kind of chaotic .once we do that , then i say , o.k. [CLS] [SEP], i 'll take one. [CLS] [SEP]that 's maybe a little bit of a different color or shape than the other ones .and i 'll say , this one is going to go in the reverse direction of the original pattern .so then we try that out .what is it like to go in the reverse pattern ?so angela throws to david , david throws to me and so on and so forth .once we 've got that down , we add these back in .so these three are going forwards in the pattern , this one 's going reverse in the pattern .and what that 's going to do is these guys are going to sometimes go to the same person at the same time .we 're going to have this multitasking situation .and we 're going to see how people deal with that , when this person 's wanting this from them and this person 's wanting that from them , and they 're feeling on the spot and under pressure .once we do a round of those , then i add in a totally different kind of ball like this and these go around the circle .so you have to say the names and toss them around in the circle .so i 've go three of these .so i have three going around the circle , three going in the order .one going in reverse order , and that 's when things are really crazy and chaotic .it 's super fun though when you stop at each round. [CLS] [SEP]and you talk about what 's going on inside your head. [CLS] [SEP], what is this experience like and how can we achieve it better ?people start learning how to slow down , to take care of their partner and connect with them , to make sure they 're ready for whatever ball or whatever idea you 're receiving them .it 's a fun thing to think about .what is this in your group ?is this a client ?is this a concept ?is it a student ?what does it mean for your organization ?and there 's a wonderful debrief or conversation you can have about that activity .make sure to have the debrief and then give people a second chance to try it again , more successfully , and see how the group dynamic changes when people think about making eye contact , slowing down , taking care of each other , making each other look good and working well in the moment .

are your wrists killing you at the end of a long day 's work ?maybe you drive a car , grab onto a steering wheel all day .maybe you work at a keyboard all day , cash register .maybe you 're a musician .if so , you might suffer from carpal tunnel syndrome .in carpal tunnel syndrome we 're using our wrist muscles rather than using all the other muscles in our arms , and so all the pressure goes to our wrist .we end up with an inflame medial nerve .one of the things that we can do is to try to stretch and use the other muscles and bring more blood flow into the wrist .so using a simple wrist circle is a great way to bring blood flow into the wrist .if you 're just in a seated comfortable position and bring your arms forward .you want to tuck your thumbs in and then bring the fingers around your thumb .bring your hands together and just begin to circle , keeping the hands together and keeping the elbows straight .do n't bend your elbows and allow your shoulder blades to sink down your back .you 'll also feel this in your shoulders 'cause what we 're trying to do is work our shoulder muscles .as you rotate in one direction , you want to rotate in the other direction .and this is going to stretch the tendons in the forearms and also bring more blood flow for your wrists and hopefully soothe some of your wrist pain .i 'm cindy mastry , namaste .

[CLS] [SEP], how do i find someone by their driver 's license ?well , in many states , you ca n't find someone by their driver 's license , because it 's protected .in fact , there is a federal protection act , known as the driver 's privacy protection act , abbreviated dppa , which protects driver 's licenses , and information about those driver 's licenses , to a large extent .however , if you already have access to that individual 's driving record , you may have the driver 's license information , which you can then put into various databases , to find out whatever information you 're looking for .in other words , you already have the driver 's record legitimately , and therefore , this opens a lot of information to you , to find out about this particular individual .one other possible source , is to hire an outside third party service , to obtain this information for you .i would recommend that a third party service is probably cheaper than a private detective , and you may consider this for the cost .again , i 'm robert todd , and thank you for watching .

prerecording is a very important and very cost saving or cost effective method when you go to record a project .now prerecording essentially means you 're going to record the entire album on your own .you 're probably using a four track or maybe recording into your computer via an inbox or something or on a keyboard .some keyboards like the triton allow you to put drum sounds and add any number of string or horn simulated sounds so that you can hear how this whole album is going to sound in a rough form before you get to the studio .maybe if you do this process and you find. [CLS] [SEP]oh maybe the horn section does n't sound so good on the beginning of this tune. [CLS] [SEP]maybe try a string section instead .mess around with the different possibilities so that when you get to the studio you 're very confident about all your ideas. [CLS] [SEP], how you want the song arranged and where you want these instruments to be .this is also very integral when you 're writing other parts .so you can hear all the parts played together and perhaps the guitar part and the piano part that you wrote do n't really sound too good together. [CLS] [SEP]but they sound good on their own .this way you 'll be able to make that assessment before you get to the very expensive studio .

[CLS] [SEP]and you 're definitely just going to want to be on a ski that 's designed for you as opposed to being on a ski that 's designed for a guy who could weigh a lot more than you .they 'll have different strengths and weaknesses and stuff like that .so if you 're a women freestyle skier and you want to keep progressing as a freestyle skier , i would definitely recommend getting a women 's park ski .they 're still going to have the same tail , the same nose .you 're going to be able to do all the tricks .it 's just going to be better designed for a woman .
in winterizing your car , coolant protection is the number one thing you want to be concerned about .protecting your car with antifreeze will raise the boiling point and it will also lower the freezing point in your cooling system .the freezing point is very important in your winter months .a fifty , fifty mix of a good quality antifreeze should bring your freezing point down to minus thirty four degrees .also , antifreeze protection will keep your engine block from rust or scaling as they call it , sending small particles into your radiator which will clog it up .rust can also damage your water pump causing it to leak over a period of time .antifreeze is one of your cheapest ways of protecting your cooling system .

all right , in this clip we 're going to teach you how to do a backside boardslide .so , this one 's nice and easy ,as you come off the lip of the jump , you 're going to turn your body towards the bottom of the hill , towards the end of the rail .so , when you ollie , you 're going to turn , put your board right in between the bindings over the top of the box of the rail or whatever you 're hitting , keep your knees bent and look to where you want to go and follow it out all the way to the end .now , when you get to the end , you 're going to turn your shoulders and just ride off clean .so , make sure you keep your knees bent .and on this one you want to try -- maybe try it a little bit slower at first , so you can get the feel of the box or the rail or whatever you 're hitting. [CLS] [SEP]and then you can kinda progress up a little bit quicker .so make sure you land flat based , 'cause if you 're leaning too far on your toes , your edge is going to dig into the metal or the plastic or whatever you 're sliding , you 're just going to fall forward .if you lean too far back , you 're just going to slide out on your butt like that .so , make sure you land flat based , keep your knees bent and look to where you want to go .

[CLS] [SEP]so i 'll give that a shot. [CLS] [SEP]and it looks like. [CLS] [SEP]that is a little bit too high now .so you can turn the barrel counterclockwise to release some cable tension and that looks good right there .many times what can also cause a derailer to shift improperly is a bent derailer hanger which we will cover later .again another thing which would cause your derailer to shift improperly would be too short length of cable housing or also too long .if it is way out and curvy and a lot of cable has to pull through there it can get hung up inside there and not shift properly and also if it is too short then the cable will be kind of trying to pull itself out of the derailer because it is so short .another quick fix that you can do is also if your bike is little bit older. [CLS] [SEP]it may or may not have barrel adjusters. [CLS] [SEP]so if you ca n't seem to find one of those either on the handle bar or at the derailer , just take your 5 mm allen. [CLS] [SEP]and you would loosen your derailer cable anchor. [CLS] [SEP]screw there. [CLS] [SEP]and then just pull the cable through taut with your hand and then lock that screw down again and then do the same task , give it a little more or a little less based on how well the bike is shifting .it looks like a little bit too much so give it just a little bit less .great. [CLS] [SEP]that looks good and that is how you adjust an improperly shifting derail .

the next type of trail we are going to be talking about is the bunny trail .this is generally where learners first start off , where lessons take place and where people who have just come out of lessons or do n't want to move on to a real trail yet go .you are not going to be using a chair lift most of them use something that looks like an escalator and think of it as a moving sidewalk. [CLS] [SEP]and if they do n't have that and a little bit of a rope tow then you just stand up and hold on to a ring and pull yourself up .as you move beyond the bunny slope you are going to have to start tackling the chair lift. [CLS] [SEP]but right now on the bunny slope you are probably not going to have to deal with that .the bunny slope in tradition is usually the shortest and least steep trail out of all of them completely flat .it is just supposed to help you gain your balance on the board or skis .they do n't want to you know throw you to the wolves and have you on some kind of terrain that you ca n't control yourself on and basically it is just there to help you gain confidence on the board .
the next game we 're going to talk about is the bunny hunt , and the bunny hunt works as follows .one player volunteers to be the bunny , and everyone else are the hunters .now you have two options where the bunny is concerned .you can have all of the hunters have unlimited paint and the bunny can have one hopper full of paint and a shield , and you can have a shield that 's made of a trash can lid or a small piece of plexiglass .just something roughly the diameter of a garbage can lid or option b.you can give the bunny as much paint as he can carry , as much paint as he wants to carry and limit each of the hunter to twenty rounds per hunter , and when the hunter is out of paint then he has to walk off the field .no sharing of ammunition among the hunters .so the game is very simple beyond that .once you 've decided upon the option the bunny will then be given a five minute head start to enter the field .the bunny will take his position up on the field and after five minutes the horn will go off to let the bunny know that the game has begun .then the hunters enter the field and then the objective of the game of course for the hunters is to kill the bunny .the objective of the bunny is simply to survive .
so let me explain scoliosis .there are two parts of scoliosis .all the other ones have a simple curve , either out or in , does n't matter it has a curve .scoliosis has an s and a c curve so your spine is doing some wacky stuff at this time .so regular c curve means that you are kind of pushed in , like one side is dominant and one side is lax .then you have an s curve which means everything here is fine and everything here is fine in a way. [CLS] [SEP]but maybe this side shifts a little bit. [CLS] [SEP]and then this side shifts .you really ca n't tell the s curve unless you favor one side more than the other , the upper side or the lower .the majority of people have an s curve deficiency because one side is more dominant than the other .that comes from when you grow and you do not really treat the curve it is always going to tend to go to one side , the one that is more dominant .we are now going to work on ways to treat the s tendency curve .

i 've won championships both as a coach and a player .let 's talk about the shooting motion .a really good shooter will tell you that establishing a shooting routine is crucial .what i mean by that is always making sure that your feet are set .always making sure that your feet are pointed towards the basket .having them be no wider than your shoulders .having your knees bent , ready to receive the basketball .when you receive the basketball , being ready to shoot the basketball .it does n't matter if somebody 's running at you , or if you 're wide open .your motion is the same every time , ever time , every time .receive the basketball. [CLS] [SEP], we 've got our feet set. [CLS] [SEP], our shoulders , we 're -- our feet point towards the rim ,our shoulders set for the receipt , we catch the ball , we go up in our range with the ball in our fingertips , not resting on our palm -- on our fingertips .as we release the ball , it comes off of our fingertips , and we always finish high .release the ball , finish high .ball on the tips , release off the tips , finish high .feet set , shoulders set , ball on the tips , finish high .feet set , shoulders set , receive the ball on the fingertips , off the fingertips , finish high .that is the correct shooting motion , and should be done the same way every time , every time , every time .learn how to shoot , become a sharpshooting basketball player .

okay , let 's talk about a hot tip for dialog processing .now , as we remember we sent all of our dialog tracks to a single bus , right .we took all of our dialogs into the bus one , all of our effects into bus three , four , and music to five and six .let 's go down to that auxiliary bus , okay .i 'm going to be setting up what 's called the dialog chain .now this is one things that some mixers like to keep private or secretive , but this is one of the things i 've learned when i started working with sound mixes in an analog studio , working with film magnetics stock back and forth and. [CLS] [SEP]so forth in the mixing studio .i do the same filtering essentially , and i 've just converted to pro tools .i take all my dialog , send it to a group of plug-ins all chained together .but in this case , i 'm going to put all the plug-ins on one dialog auxiliary .so the first thing i like to do with. [CLS] [SEP]all of my dialog is i like to go through and run it through a equalizer .i 'm going to pick an equalizer , and this case we 'll use a seven band e.q .that 'll work fine , but i 'm only going to use the top and bottom .all dialog needs a little bit of processing and band passing .so what i 'm going to do is i 'm going to put a band pass and take out all the low frequencies that do not belong with dialog .human speech only goes from around one-hundred hertz up to ten , fifteen k , so anything below that is occupied by rumble and wind , all the stuff we do n't want on our dialog tracks .so we take care of that , we put that filter in .and then we , i put a filter on the very , very , very top .this is to get rid of mike noise , hiss , and those sorts of things , back when i was working with sixteen millimeter meg , it used to be just a tape noise .so in this case , i 'm going to be a little more forgiving. [CLS] [SEP], i 'm going to actually put tha band. [CLS] [SEP]pass up way high. [CLS] [SEP], i 'm going to put it around fifteen k.so , as you can see here , i have a nice little curve , top and bottom gets rolled off .okay , after that , i gp ahead. [CLS] [SEP]and i put in an equalizer ,i 'm sorry , after the equalizer , i go ahead and put in a compressor .now the compressor is something that , generally when you start with these , they have a built in band pass .look at that , this one has a built in band pass in it .a lot of these compressor come in with nice presets .that 's something you 'll have to find out for yourself .but , basically the way they work is , they will limit the dynamics of the audio .so if somebody gets too loud it keeps it down and that 's a good way of containing your dialog .i like to make sure that the dialog just kisses the compressor , and sometimes you do n't need to put any compression on it at all , and the way we affect that is by the threshold .we want to play our track. [CLS] [SEP]and we want to adjust the threshold so that it 's not actually hitting at all .and that 's an optimal setting right there .so , i 've set it. [CLS] [SEP]so it 's just touching , and that gives us a good setting for our compressor .
to begin , we 're going to look at the different types of writing tools that you might use .you have a choice .easiest , cheapest and most readily available , i hope , are calligraphy markers , which work like so .they have a broad nib and a skinny side .however , as with all things that are cheap and easy to find , the calligraphy nibs eventually soften over time and you 're going to see that your hairlines get thicker and the edges of the nib get kind of squished down .so the alternative is to use a steel nibbed pen .and a steel nib pen is going to give you the beautiful broad lines , just make sure i do n't have too much ink , and also beautiful hairlines and a little more control than the marker .so my recommendation is if you at all can , and sometimes people ca n't manage the pen , i would suggest starting out with a steel nib pen which is the historic tool for writing , for beautiful writing .the nibs come in a variety of sizes .here i have a c0 , which is a big one , and a c1 , which is the next size down .you can see there 's a little bit of difference there .what you want to avoid are the nibs that are pointed because pointed nibs , this nib is not the correct nib to use , will not do the proper writing technique that we 're going to be working on .now here 's another one , a different brand of nib .this one comes from japan , it 's a tape nib .so to start i would say get a large nib and work with that , whether it 's marker or steel nib .
in order to take a chip shot , you want to try and kick the ball over the top of the goal keeper to dip into the goal , so we have to be aware of the goalkeeper 's positioning .when the goalkeeper is not in the goal on his or her goal line , that is a opportunity for use to take a chip shot .the technique behind taking a chip shot. [CLS] [SEP], it involves getting underneath the ball to create loft so that the ball will then come back down and into the back of the net .let 's show that with the demonstrators .our non kicking foot is placed beside the ball , our kicking foot , with the toe down , gets underneath the ball to create the chip that we require , over the goalkeeper and into the goal .that is how we take a chip shot .

okay , prior to doing the actual chains , i just want to point out one more time .i hope i put the information out a little bit earlier .make sure you always check your owner ?s manual and get what the vehicle manufacturer requires for chains .there are some vehicles where they 're not recommended use on , other applications , four wheel drives , where they recommend you have them on all four wheels or not at all .it is a good idea , if you can have chains on your rear , that just gives you that much more breaking and cornering stability .it wo n't help you on acceleration too much on front wheel drive cars but the breaking is dramatically increased .so , that being said , this is standard type s chain and that 's a rating used for automobiles .that basically means it 's requirements , it needs about an inch and a half of over tread clearance and somewhere in the neighborhood of between a half and three quarters of an inch on sidewall clearance .what that means is how much extra space you have to have around the tire to give the chains adequate clearance. [CLS] [SEP]so they wo n't damage the vehicle .we 're well within our parameters here .now we just want to drape that over the tire and get it centered real good .go kind of front to back and all the way around .we 're going to want to make that rear connection first .that 's down around the back side of the tire .to give you a little better idea , we 're going to give you a little different shot of that. [CLS] [SEP], i only have one option .it 's going to have to be able to be notched .we know it fits correctly , when it 's off the car .so it should fit on there when the vehicle , when the tires mounted back on .so if it 's not going to pull together for you and make a connection .you need to move the snow out of the way or what 's ever impeding the chains ability to come all the way down here to the bottom of the tire .once the rears connected , we just simply make that front connection all the way down to the last notch .then the next step is to put the tensioners on .please watch our next segment ; we 'll cover installing the tensioners .
in restorative yoga , there 's many benefits .not only , we could distress and center yourself more and be able to face your day. [CLS] [SEP], you sleep better and things like that .a great way to find a relaxation is think of several parts of your body .for example , to relax your jaw and these are things to think about as we go to the serious postures later on .relax the jaw , just swallow a few times and let the jaw hang open .at the same time as you start to relax , your cheeks will feel hollow , allow them to feel hollow , jaw 's slightly open .focus on the breath and just let yourself melt into the floor .and these are good indicators to figure out where you are tension-wise .you want your hands to relax , so you do n't want to keep them out too far , you want to have them just nice and relax on the floor as you lay down in these postures that i 'm about to show you .and when you close the eyes , let the eyelids be heavy , let the bottom lid meet the upper lid and let the eyes roll back in the head and find that nice peaceful tranquil feeling of being relax .many people are concern , `` i ca n't relax , i ca n't relax '' .if you focus on trying to find relaxation , you will be frustrated .but if you focus on concentrating on individual body parts , it will help as a whole body relaxation .

[CLS] [SEP]and then you can do 2 ,5 into the minor .those are just some simple ideas for creating some basic chord structures in the key of g flat major .
okay , right now we 're going to talk about white balance .white balance is how you compensate to try to get pure white from different kinds of lighting situations .let 's say for example , that you 're outside in daylight .well , daylight , because it reflects off the sky , is more of a blue type light but if you go into lighting on an interior of a house that 's incandescent lighting , it 's got more of a yellow tone to it , so everything is toned yellow .it 's got , in cameras. [CLS] [SEP]today you 've got automatic white balance. [CLS] [SEP]but you can also adjust it to get perfect balance and custom balance depending on your capabilities .so let 's start out and take a look at this .we 're going to click on this and white balance. [CLS] [SEP]is the first thing that comes up .so you can go into the white balance by going to the right because it shows a little arrow there , and then we 've got. [CLS] [SEP], that 's daylight and it shows you the different colors .right down here , it 's blue. [CLS] [SEP]so it gives you a sort of blue filter effect , when you 're using incandescent and it will do an automatic white balance as well too .but for some people that 's not good enough .you can click on this and go to white balance adjust. [CLS] [SEP]and then you can adjust your white balance , and it shows you what you 're doing to your subject when you do that .you can adjust it in different ways , so it will change your tint and coloration of the while balance .

[CLS] [SEP]i would not want to punch him like that and stop short of his face .what you actually do is you form a frame around shaun 's head right there or whoever you 're acting with. [CLS] [SEP], you want to for a frame. [CLS] [SEP]and you want to punch outside of that frame or. [CLS] [SEP]you want to slap outside of that frame .you never want to just slap and stop and you always want a good follow through so that the audience knows that you went through with the whole punch or the whole slap .another important thing to know aside from the distance from the person and where around the head you 're going to hit them is that you always want to work slower than you actually would if you 're really hitting somebody .if you 're doing something on stage the audience is there to watch the action not someone really get punched .so you really want to over exaggerate. [CLS] [SEP]and you want to go slower .when you get it all practiced out. [CLS] [SEP]you want to go at the most 75 % of the actual speed. [CLS] [SEP]you would if you were really hitting him .once again when you 're practicing and you 're first learning your moves you always want to start at quarter speed , you want it really slow just so you can get the physical movement down and start memorizing it that way .those are some basic things you need to know about hitting or punching someone .

the g natural minor scale is extracted from the b flat major scale .therefore it has f sharp turning to f natural , e going to e flat , and b going b flat , so we have g , a , b flat , c , d , e flat , f , and g. [CLS] [SEP]quite a difference from the major scale .the g minor scale once again .

[CLS] [SEP], he 's got his eyes closed .now , the eyes closed , that 's a personal preference thing .in yoga , they 're very adamant actually , about keeping your eyes open , most of the time because they feel it puts you more in the here and now .some people , including myself , like to stretch with their eyes closed because it really helps them to withdraw , within themselves , relax a little bit more and kind of gain a little bit more muscular control or relaxing of muscles .you would normally spend a little bit more time , in each stretch .he 's kind of abbreviating them , just a little bit , just to show you some different variations .and again , he 's probably trying to loosen up and stretch out of some of the tight areas like his lower back would be .most important , i notice he 's not intensely pushing , any of these stretches , it 's all about just going to the edge of , where your stretch is , and getting your body to loosen up .he 's doing a lot of switching , to go into a lot of different muscle groups here , now he 's going to bend his leg back , behind him .when you do this , when you get your knee over to the side like this , it now makes the stretch a lot more intense , on your front hamstring .notice he 's going to reach forward , with his hands , his eyes are closed again and there 's varying opinions , as far as this back knee , back here thing .some people , they do n't like it. [CLS] [SEP], they think that it 's hard on the knee , if you do it and your knee hurts , i certainly would suggest shying away from this stretch but. [CLS] [SEP]generally , if you can keep this back part of your leg tucked in behind you , then you 're going to keep from getting any pain , in this knee right here .like with any stretch , if you have any discomfort , make sure you discontinue it , right away .some people get a great stretch out of this one , from this front leg because it definitely makes it very intense , on the hamstring .he 's sinking deeply , into each stretch .switching hands .

what we are going to demonstrate and talk about now is the proper method to secure a tarpaulin or some other type of covering or to secure a rope between two objects called the trucker 's hitch .the trucker 's hitch is basically coming off a substantial object with a piece of rope .the rope would then go around whatever anchor point. [CLS] [SEP]we are going to use and we would come back to the end of the rope and form a figure of eight on a bite around the other end of that rope .once the figure of eight on the bite is formed it gives us a place to run our rope through by placing the rope either through that eye or taking the end of the rope through that eye and pulling it tight .this stretches our rope between our two anchor points , we then take our piece of rope after we get the rope secured and stretched tight and we wrap it around and secure with a clove hitch to finish off the knot .it 's a self tightening knot , it can be slid along , stretched tight and then secured with a clove hitch at the end .simple trucker 's hitch to secure a rope between two objects or stretch a tarpaulin tight .
sitting around and watching television , calling and chatting with friends , all of these things are n't necessarily working towards getting the job done .so , you want to make sure that you regiment yourself with certain disciplines as you 're going through your day-to-day work life .for example , you want to make sure that you 're up at a certain time everyday .you want to make sure that you get showered , get dressed as if you were actually going to a real office .all of these things might seem bizarre at the beginning but they really add up when it comes to sitting down in front of your desk and getting work done .also , you want to make sure that televisions , radios , pdas , anything where you could be -- instant messaging online , distracting websites , can all keep you from actually getting your work done .so , sometimes , working for a certain period of time and then stopping and taking a break can be a good way to reward yourself for completing the task at hand .

something to remember when you are using warm and cool colors , when you 're mixing them on your color palette , when you mix them together , the warm and cool colors , if you mix cool colors with cool colors and warm colors with warm colors , it 's hard to go around. [CLS] [SEP]but when you start mixing the two together , it 's easy to get muddy colors .muddy colors would be something that would n't really be definable as any certain color .you really want to have colors that are really going to be definable as something you know like a bluish green or a light-pinky purple or something like even if they 're not real words of anything , you want to be able to like have it as like a real color and not like a muddy area on your painting because it does make a difference .like when you 're looking at your composition as a whole , you can spot the places that have the muddy colors and that 's , you really , really want to try and avoid that because it does make a difference so just try and be careful when you are mixing warm and cool colors .
so flowers are another high value crop that we do n't want to ignore in the permaculture garden .flowers not only give beauty , and beautiful odor , they not only attract beneficial insects and bugs , but they also tend to delineate and define the garden .so in other words , we 're going to use these , a gladiola bulbs , the flowers that you often see in funerals and wedding and such , long , spikey , elegant flowers .we 're going to tuck these in the ground , and get rapid results , because we have these very robust little bulbs .in order to grow them quickly , we want to fill a generous supply of well rotted manure in each hole .and then tuck them in , preferably root side down , although they will find their way up , like so .you can see some of the color variation here , that 'll give us lots of interesting permutations .and from there , we merely want to cover them over , with this beautiful rich soil , tuck them in , mulch them in , and then try not to plant over them .remember that we 've planted our bulbs here , and not to double plant .these bulbs should be showing , within two weeks we should see them , and within a month they should be shooting up .that 's just one of many , many perennial flower bulbs that we can incorporate into the perennial garden .

when we 've talked about communication , it 's always been from the standpoint of making sure that your team can , can communicate effectively on the field .and we 've talked about verbal codes and there 's a lot of cases where verbal codes are exactly the wrong thing to do .in many cases , especially if you 're stalking an opponent 's position , you may be getting closer and closer to him. [CLS] [SEP]and he still not know that you 're there .you may be trying to get up underneath a bunker and crawl in to a position where you 'll be able to assist another teammate in bunkering that opposing player .so in those cases , it 's critical that you still be able to communicate without giving away your position to the opposing team and. [CLS] [SEP]and and thus opening up yourself for a counter attack .in those cases visual communications become essential .that is why in all of the , in the military , in special forces , delta force , the seals , they have an entire library of these signals and can communicate complex strategy without saying a word .the , learning and employing hand signals is a great way to strengthen your team 's performance on the field .

chinese writing is very different from most other languages in the world .in the chinese writing system , chinese symbols represent each character which corresponds to a single spoken syllable .a majority of words in all modern varieties of chinese require two or more characters to write .many chinese characters were adopted according to their meaning by the japanese and korean languages to represent native words , disregarding pronunciation altogether .chinese characters are also considered to be the world 's longest continuously used writing system .

when you 're ready to go outside and use our telescope , there are couple of things you should have in order to make your night viewing a better experience .one , is to find a light that is a red light .now , why would you want to use a red light ?well , you 'd want to use a red light because white light destroys your night vision .it takes about five minutes for your night vision to build up .now , this particular light has both the white , if you flip it one way , and the red .so , it 's very handy .so , when you 're at night and you 're out by your telescope , use the red light .you can simply get a flashlight and use red fingernail polish and point over the lens and that works fine as well .the other thing that you should take with you , and this is really a key thing for astronomy , a good binocular .these are 750 's , they 're inexpensive binoculars , good way to get started .you have the ability to see all kinds of incredible things with binoculars .when you use binoculars make sure that you tuck your arms underneath to steady them and then move back .you may want to lean against a tree .but , by taking even the small binocular that we have here and scanning the night sky in the summer , up through the milky way , you 'll see some incredibly galaxies and nebulae and just star clusters that 'll blow your mind .

hi !my name is lynn loughmiller. [CLS] [SEP]and i have been asked to talk a little bit about budgeting .when i was first married , we started budgeting and it was just a very simple type of budget that we used .we created envelopes and when i got paid , we would cash the check and put money in these separate envelopes .we would pay utility bills and other bills first and money that was left over we would budget into different accounts .the reason i liked this budget so much is that we had budgets for dating and budgets for just our own personal , even if it was only $ 10 , it was nice that i knew that i had $ 10 out of my paycheck to spend on whatever i wanted to .that was kind of fun .we had a budget for dating because we always knew on a monthly or weekly basis there was at least some money we could use to date or do something fun. [CLS] [SEP]and if we did n't have that budget , we would n't have had that extra money because we would have used it for all of these other things where money kind of disappears when you do n't know where your money is .so that was a great introduction to budgets .as i got into the professional world , i started into creating budgets within businesses and it was over a training department. [CLS] [SEP]and we had to create budgets so that we could submit to have money for our year. [CLS] [SEP]and we had to be able to spend within that budget .recently we acquired a few different businesses and in doing that , budgets are critical .they help me sleep better at night .when i am really worried about where our money is going , i look at our budget and compare it to money that is going in and out. [CLS] [SEP]and i look at it .i say , okay , this is how it is doing , this is where we are going. [CLS] [SEP]and i feel better about what is going to be happening as far as the money flowing in and out .it makes a huge difference on just your well-being and knowing that the money is working according to how you hoped it would .so in business it is absolutely critical .if you ca n't use a budget to forecast how the money is coming in , it is going to be spent .

i 'm going to show you how to do a roll down the spine from the plough position in modern dance .this is a nice way to release all of the muscles in your back , and to open up your spine .our spine have several vertebra that are stacked on top of each other , and in life we tend to squish those vertebra together .this is a way to open up your spine so that you have a little cushion space in between each vertebra .so i want you to think about that while we 're rolling down the spine .first we 're going to go into your plough position .i 'm going to reach my hands over my head , and i 'm going to reach my feet for my hands .just get into a position that 's comfortable for you .if your feet do n't reach the ground , that 's okay .you can still roll down the spine .it 's important that when we 're in the plough position , we stay there for a couple minutes before we roll down the spine .i 'm not going to stay there for the sake of time , but you should .so once i 've stayed there for a little bit , i 'm going to roll down the spine , and i 'm going to think of reaching each vertebra ,starting from my neck , one at a time , each vertebra is going to reach for the ground , until the very last , my tail bone , reaches the ground .i 'm going to do it as slow as possible. [CLS] [SEP], i 'm going to control myself as much as possible , and i 'm going to have to use my stomach muscles to do that .if you need to you can use your hands .you can put your hands by your sides to help you .so i 'm going to roll back into the plough position , and i 'm going to hang out here for a while .and once i have , i 'm slowly going to roll down the spine .slowly , reaching one vertebra at a time .if i need to i 'll put my hands down here , but try not to if you can .just relax and use a little bit of your stomach muscles , one at a time , one at a time , one at a time .i can feel each vertebra reaching .i have to remind myself to relax my arms , relax my legs , until i finally feel my tail bone on the ground .and then i 'm going to bend my knees , and just relax and fee all of the muscles in my back just releasing in the ground .that 's a great way to roll down the spine to open up the vertebra in our back and to release the muscles in our back from the plough position in modern dance .
now i 'm going to show you the different types of sugars that are present in different kinds of foods. [CLS] [SEP]and this is really important to keep in mind when you are trying to feed your children food that is going to give them sustained energy , that is not going to give them basically a sugar rush and then a crash .when that happens , you are going to notice that kids are going to get , have impatience , be irritable , they might be tired , generally crabby , not good concentration , moody , that kind of thing .so diet definitely plays a huge part in children 's behavior .what we 're going to look at right here is the first category of sugars , would be the example of a kind that you really want to minimize in your child 's diet .these are the kinds of products that contain sugars of glucose , sucrose , dextrose , granulated sugar , brown sugar .these are the kinds of sugars that are going to basically give a big burst of energy with a crash right after and they 're not something that 's going to give sustained energy , so we really want to use these minimally , these kind of products .as you can see right here , in this product the first ingredient is sugar , which is an indication that it has a lot of sugar in it and that 's the most plentiful ingredient in it .over here we have the sugars that are more naturally derived and that are much healthier to digest .they take longer for the sugar to break down , so the energy is going to be-you 're going to have more energy over a span of time , and these types of sugars are called fructose , which is from fruit and honey or lactose which would be dairy , which would be yogurt and yogurt products .again , the sugar does n't enter the blood stream quite as quickly , more steady source of energy .over here you have the what is considered the more healthy source of sugar ,the complex carbohydrates or we also call them starches .they provide more of a gradual .steady energy and. [CLS] [SEP]they 're going to leave your child feel full longer .you want to go with the whole grain breads , things like unsweetened cereals , pastas , potatoes , that kind of thing .
our next point is a really good point for just general pain .it 's called kunlun mountains or the aspirin point or bladder 60.and it actually is in this space between the achilles tendon and the bone .the particular spot is about two-thirds of the way up , but the easiest thing to do with this area is just to massage up and down in that space between the bone and the tendon .and this will soothe pain just about anywhere in the body .it 's a generalized , as it 's called the aspirin point .so it keeps the energy following , eases the pain , and can be used for any kind of painful condition .it can be used also just as a calming mechanism .it 's a nice point to use if your dog has been traumatized .you just rub in this point and it 's soothing and calming and takes away any pain .and again , it 's an up and down motion in that space between the ankle bone and where this muscle begins up above it .

[CLS] [SEP], a company that specializes in auto restoration and customization .so , now i 'm going to teach you how to determine quickly the level of commitment your vehicle is going to require if you decide to do a restoration .this is a 1956 willys wagon .the previous owner purchased it with every intention of restoring it back to its original state .so , he went out. [CLS] [SEP], he bought it , he took it back to his garage , he started tearing it in in a whirlwind weekend .and all of a sudden , he realized he had completely bitten off way more than he could chew , and so now what ; now what does he do .well , we 're going to use this as a learning experience , to show you kind of the things that you definitely need to look out for ; the big gotchas that are hidden in every single restoration project .obviously , one of the biggest ones that people have a hard time doing is rust repair .rust , rust rust , it 's a four-letter word that plagues this industry , and unfortunately , this vehicle has a lot of rust .it 's not the worst thing about it , but it is definitely one of the biggest problems .some of the telltale signs that rust is being covered up can always be found on floor pans .this floor pan has been repaired pretty poorly .somebody took a galvanized piece of sheet metal , and just riveted it down to the floor , and then sealed it up with some home depot caulking .terrible , terrible re repair , but you ca n't see it if it 's underneath carpet .so , you 've really got to get those coveralls on ; climb underneath of em ' , stab everything you can with a screwdriver to determine how much rust is really in there , because that is the biggest detriment to first time restorers actually having success with their restoration .the other thing you need to keep in mind is you just have to get a feel for the vehicle .this has duct tape holding switches to shifters .it 's got wiring coming hanging down all over the place , and it 's it 's. [CLS] [SEP]it 's just kind of a mess .that 's not to say that this restoration or this project is terrible .it just means that it might require way more than what your facility , your budget , your time commitment is going to be able to allow .this actually ; this vehicle actually has a lot of really , really good , very valuable parts , and in terms of parting it out and mixing and matching pieces from this to another project , it might be the best way to go .so if the price is right and you can buy this vehicle , and you know what parts are good and what parts are bad ahead of time , then you 're going to be a step ahead of about ninety percent of everybody else .for instance , this vehicle has a very rare electric overdrive unit , and it 's the first year of a six-cylinder engine in it , so those two items right there are worth more than what the previous owner paid for the entire vehicle .so keeping that it mind , you may just have to pound the pavement , hit e-bay and wait , join a couple car clubs .then try and find a restoration project that fits what you 're capable of , and what you need to do .

sock knitting can appear a little intimidating at the beginning because there are a few steps around the hell area that are a little complicated .but i 've broken up the parts of the sock in this little test sock into different colors to give you an idea of what 's involved .at the top here in purple is a ribbing .you always want to do a ribbing because that will hold your sock up .then you are going to do the leg .you 're going to switch to the leg .and you 'll make that as long or as short as you want .there are people that make socks that are just little like tennis socks , or you can have knee socks .after the sock you are going to go into the heel flap , back here in blue .and there are different ways to knit it to reinforce it so that it 's more durable .after the heel flap you are going to go into turning the heel , which is this green .and there 's your little heel .then you have to work out the gusset to get back to the stitches required for the measurement of your foot .and that 's this white section here .that 's decreasing to get to the size of your foot .then you 're going to want to work the length of your foot .obviously this is a test sock .no ones feet are like this .and in the end you are going to be working the blue portion which is shaping your toe .

okay the next combination we 're going to discuss. [CLS] [SEP]and i 'm going to elaborate on. [CLS] [SEP]is what we call a left jab , left hook .this combination gives you the element of surprise .it 's a very frustrating punch for your opponent .what happens is you faint the left jab , and as you 're stepping in you come back and throw a good , solid left hook to the head , and then you step back out again .what happens is as you throw that first left jab to the face of your opponent , he 's going to be bringing up his hands ; he 's going to be going onto the defense .all of a sudden , out of nowhere comes a left hook to the side of his head , and he almost looked around as if to say , `` hey is there another boxer in here ? ''or he looks up at the stands to see if his mom just saw him get embarrassed because of a punch that he did n't expect coming from anywhere .normally when you throw the left jab , you bring it straight back .you step back and you bring it straight back to your cheek .you throw the jab and bring it straight back .in this case what we 're going to do is , we 're going to throw the left , and instead of bringing it right back to our cheek , we 're going to continue to slide forward , getting up alongside of our opponent , protecting ourself with our right hand .that 's also important .we 're down in this position anyway , so come out of it with a good left hook to the head , and then step back .okay ?so a little bit faster - left jab , left hook , step back ;left jab , left hook , step back ; left jab , left hook , step back ; left , hook , step back .hopefully you 'll surprise your opponent and frustrate them .there 's nothing like a frustrated boxer , easier to get .

in warrior training , what it does is it develops your resilience spirit .warrior training is not just about the combative martial arts .a real warrior is somebody whose very resilient , who does n't give up .there was an old japanese adage that say , 'if you get knocked down seven times , give up the eighth time '' .that 's what the warrior training is about .it 's similar to yoga and that we use this physical principles , be it kickboxing or jiu jitsu to reach a higher plane .historically , the martial arts was about the spirit and conditioning the spirit through physical body , similar to hatha yoga .so a lot of times in warrior training , we often go back to the meditation , to the physicality and all the different components that comprise warrior training .
alright , this next exercise is called eight up four back .it 's about stop and go , and acceleration .i 'm going to demonstrate it to you right now .you 'll sprint up eight steps and make a hard stop , and then straight into a back peddle for four steps , and then accelerate back up eight more , stop , four more , sprint back out , eight again , and that 's the exercise .okay .you ready ?ready .start back out .up eight , back four .perfect .let 's do it again , one more time .good hard stops , perfect .okay , the benefits of doing that drill is helping you go backwards , helping you go forwards .sometimes you 'll have a quick guard who likes to give it to you like that .you can get it and get it back .

[CLS] [SEP]you 're bored or you 're anxious to get away from whatever you 're doing or angry .it creates a totally different attitude than if you 're posing to show that you 're relaxed and feel good in the clothing that you 're wearing .and as i seem parallel against the floor with my arms , i want you to slightly drop the right shoulder .just slightly drop that right shoulder not. [CLS] [SEP]the left shoulder , let it stay relaxed and this is your pose number six .it 's important that if you find yourself holding your elbow , release the elbow , slide down just a little bit so that you still see the right fingers on your right hand over the left bicep .but you also clearly see that your arms are relaxed .like for this sweater that i 'm wearing , it 's the typical pose that you would do in a sweater , so that you can just see it 's restful and cozy to wear this sweater .also , keep the basic the same with the twist in the hip and again occasionally smile into the camera so that you know you 're relaxed and having fun doing pose five and six .

[CLS] [SEP]-- we drag it underneath the original .so we want the original on top , and then you want this one on the bottom -- that copy layer .and you can tell it 's a copy layer because it says right there .and we might even want to go ahead and double click on there , and name that -- we 'll name it actual reflection .this is just going to be the reflection layer .and if you can see that i go up here and click on my move tool with the top .now i have a way to move this layer down , and this is the start of our reflection .and this is how you copy a layer to make that reflection , and then on the next tutorial i 'm going to teach you guys how to free transform this to make it look even more realistic .

[CLS] [SEP], i mean that 's definitely the brightest color that 's used .but the blue and the green up here are also quite bright .they 're darker but they are similarly bright .down as we move down this , we stay in the blue-green range , but we 're getting a lot more neutral .as we move down our color is a lot less neutral there than it is up here .and what that does is sort of make it fade away a little bit .so again you know , the more you can control your changes .not just the value , but of saturation , the more you can really control what goes in , what goes out .you know , how much contrast there is .obviously you know , there 's a lot strong contrast here of value .that 's dark , that 's light .up here let 's see .up here it 's more , here it 's more a terms of saturation .that 's a brighter color than this is .also this is warm and this is cool .so essentially , this sits in front of this corner .and that 's how the color theory kind of comes together .warm sticks out , cool recedes .stronger value contrasts jump , lesser value contrasts recede .and in general warm colors come out , cool colors recede and brightness also .the bright colors take your eye more than the dull colors .

we 're focusing on some footwork right now , we 're going to be working on what 's called chase step .okay , to perform the chase step , i 'll show it to you a few times nice and slow .okay , so this is one of the primary stepping that we do in xing yi .the idea with this is to move forward and to follow up with your body .again , i move forward , follow up .the follow up is important because the follow up , boom , is how we 're generating a lot of force , we 're hitting with our whole body .okay , going the other way for you .as a beginner , you want to kind of come up nice and high , and make sure your weight is on the rear leg , it goes sixty percent , forty percent .okay .and then we step , chase step .chase , step .as you get better with it , you take a bigger step forward and a bigger chase up .your forward foot is striking the ground with your heel .the rear leg is generating force by pushing down and exploding forward .this is how we perform chase step , xing yi beginners .

[CLS] [SEP], okay ?so how far am i going to be sitting away from it ?the trick is , if you 're sitting closer to the television , you can buy a smaller monitor and have it appear like a larger monitor .i ... [CLS] [SEP]and from there , your primary use .am i going to be using it to ... [CLS] [SEP]for watching movies , broadcast television , play video games ?each one of those will lead you down and narrow the selection .your basic selections are this : whether you want to go standard definition or sd tv , or high definition or hd tv .and then from there , if you want high definition , which i highly recommend , you 've got to decide whether you want an lcd television , like the one that i 'm standing next to , a dlp or a digital light projection television , or a plasma ,all right ?and each of them have better uses .some of them are better in high light situations like the lcd , some are better for playing video games like the dlp , all right ?plasma and dlp being the highest , and you 're going to pay the highest price .there 's also rear projection televisions , which i like a lot .you can get yourself a very large television in rear projection in high definition and save a few dollars .so remember , how much do i have to spend ?what am i using it ?where is it going from ?with a little bit of research and kicking some tires ...no , do n't .do n't kick the monitors , but you know what i mean .do some window shopping and a little bit more research , and you 'll find the best tv monitor for you .i 'm rokosz , your digital lifestyle expert , saying , `` stream you later . now i 'll be discussing zils .now , earlier we used the word zils to describe the two metal parts on a tambourine that vibrate against each other , so here , just a set of zils would be on a tambourine .now , zils more generally would refer to what you would know as finger cymbals .now , these are from india , but you 'll see them in in different countries in the middle east .now the idea between these two instruments is to vibrate against each other .you 'll see this in tibet even , in religious ceremonies , where you 'll hit two cymbals , and the slight difference in tone between the two cymbals creates oscillation , basically meaning it 's slightly out of tune from one another to create a vibration sound .now , they can also be used for dancers , so like belly dancers , for example , would use these instruments , but they would keep them on one hand ; they might even have a pair of them like you saw in castanets , where they have one hand and the other hand creating different rhythms as they dance .

today i 'm going to show you how to properly lube a bike chain and how to lube up a rusty bike chain .first thing to do would be to start by cleaning the chain .for that you can use a good citrus degreaser biodegradable .works great for dissolving all the gunk that builds up on the chain and. [CLS] [SEP]for that we 'll just peddle the bike .while spraying a slight amount on the chain .you only need about two or three peddle rotations and then take a rag and your going to just hold the chain on the bottom and run it through that rag .as you peddle it .it should remove most of the rust and dirt and grime and once you 've cleaned the chain .you can then reapply a good coating of chain lube .this particular one is a teflon based lubricant .it works really well for bike chains .it will also inhibit the rust from forming .basically the same process as cleaning .you 're just going to peddle slowly while dripping it onto the chain .same thing. [CLS] [SEP]about three peddle rotations is all you need and then let it sit for about five to ten seconds and let it soak in and then take your rag and your going to try and remove any of the excess lube .that has accumulated on the outside of the chain .the only thing that it does on the outside of the chain .is help to attract more dirt .it 's not actually benefiting the chain at all. [CLS] [SEP]and there you have a properly lubed chain. [CLS] [SEP]and you probably want to do this .you know , about once every week or two .especially if your living in a very wet environment or at the beach .where chains are very prone to rusting very quickly and that should help prevent rust from forming and keep your bike running smooth .that 's how to lube a chain .

[CLS] [SEP]they forget a lot of the good posture , and the grace , and the poise .you might find yourself forgetting to have your fingers closed .you might find yourself hunching over a lot .okay ?just remember the basics , good posture .you want to look graceful .these are some of the mistakes that you can make , and how to avoid them .

if you 're doing the layout of your own book , there 's several things that you need to know .no matter whether you 're using a word processing program , like microsoft word , or a layout program , like quark express , you need to remember that your margins have to be set correctly .be sure that your interior margins , which is along the side , have a wider margin than your exterior ones .but your exterior margins need to be at least a half an inch from the edge of you page .your interior margins need to be at least three quarters of an inch , sometimes more depending on how thick your book is , and how much space , because you do n't want your words running in to the spine of your book .so , talk to whatever publisher you 're planning on using , see if they have dimensions for you , and if you 're planning on printing it yourself , just make sure to allow that extra space on the interior of your page .if you 'll notice , you 've got about a half an inch from your exterior to the edge of your page , and your margins here .half an inch to three quarters at the top and bottom will allow you to put your headers and footers on your pages .you want to make sure that you have at least three quarters of an inch on your interior or spine so that your copy does n't run in to the middle of the page , and it 's easily readable .and good luck and have fun .

[CLS] [SEP]so we want to be able to decide what we want to light and what we do n't want to light .
